12.title: Patterns and components

13.title: Design interactions in a logical order
13.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Design interactions in a logical order
Users must be able to interact with a service using only a keyboard. This is because:


using a mouse is impossible for people who can’t see the pointer
some people don’t have the ability to control a pointing device like a mouse
many people without disabilities prefer to use a keyboard

This is a requirement of:





WCAG 2.1.1 - Keyboard (Level A)


Good tab stop design allows keyboard users to:


access all of the services interactive elements in a predictable order
identify which element currently has the input focus.
poorly-designed tab stops create high-impact accessibility problems



  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    Use visual hierarchy in HTML to flow left to right top to bottom.
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    Don’t confuse the logical order .
  

Example of testing tab stop on a webpage
You can use tools such as Accessibility Insights (opens in new tab) browser plugin to test tab stops. You should also tab through your page to see if elements are selected in the order intended.

Tools you can use


Accessibility insights to test tab stop order

14.title: Controls for content that starts automatically are provided

15.title: Do not use colour alone to convey information
15.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Do not use colour alone to convey information
Do not use colour as the only way to explain or signal something. Some people have colour vision deficiencies. Instead, use a combination of colour, shapes and text to convey meaning.
This is a requirement of:





WCAG 1.4.1 - Use of colour (Level A)


When using colour to differentiate elements, also provide additional information that does not rely on colour perception. For example, use an asterisk or text in addition to colour to indicate required form fields, and use labels to distinguish areas on graphs.
An example of this which is common is displaying a Red, Amber or Green (RAG) statuses on reports. Instead of using color alone, display text to indicate the status alongside the color.
You must also ensure when using text on colored backgrounds, you are meeting minimum contrast ratios.


  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    Provide the information conveyed with colour through another method. For example, use text so users who cannot perceive colour can still understand the information.
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    Using colour on it’s own will make it hard for colourblind users to understand what is being presented to them.
  

Tools you can use


Colorblind Web Page Filter

Additional tools for checking color contrast can be found on the Ensure sufficient contrast between foreground and background page.

16.title: Make navigation options clear and consistent across the service
16.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Make navigation options clear and consistent across the service
When using a service or website, users should expect a consistent presentation of repeated content such as navigation menus and layout of pages, and an indication of where they are.
This is a requirement of:





WCAG 3.2.3 - Consistent Navigation (Level AA)


Being consistent helps screen reader users or magnifier users to quickly navigate a set of pages as they can expect repeating features to be in the same place or order over similar pages.
This also assists users to understand where they are in a service and navigate to other areas quickly. You can do this by using breadcrumbs (opens in new tab) and  back links (opens in new tab) as appropriate.


  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    Indicate to users where they are in your service and provide affordances like breadcrumbs and back links consistently.
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    Users will be confused if it’s not clear where they are or how to navigate your service easily.
  

Tools you can use

17.title: Branding your service
17.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Branding your service
You need to make sure the service uses the right header, footer and typeface for where it’s being provided, or you risk confusing users.
Your site must look like GOV.UK if it’s on one of the following domains:


gov.uk/myservice
myservice.service.gov.uk
myblog.blog.gov.uk

You should follow the guidance on the GOV.UK Service Manual for making the service look like GOV.UK (opens in new tab)
Example of the GOV.UK header branding

If the service is on education.gov.uk
You should make changes to your branding if you are using the GOV.UK prototype kit or GOV.UK Frontend and are providing your service on an education.gov.uk domain.


  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    
    
    Use the Crest logo
    Use Department for Education as the organisation name
    Use a cross-platform compatible font-stack
    
    
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    
      
    Use the Crown or GOV.UK logotype
    Use the GDS Transport typeface
    Identify as being part of GOV.UK when it’s not
    
    
  

Example of a cross-platform compatible font-stack
body {
    font-family: -apple-system,
        BlinkMacSystemFont,
        "Segoe UI",
        Roboto,
        Oxygen-Sans,
        Ubuntu,
        Cantarell,
        "Helvetica Neue",
        sans-serif !important;
}
Example of the DfE header branding

DFE header code snippet

18.title: Make it easy for people to identify interactive elements
18.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Make it easy for people to identify interactive elements
This is a requirement of:





WCAG 2.4.7 - Focus Visible (Level AA)







WCAG 3.2.4 - Consistent Identification (Level AA)




  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    Make it obvious when componenets which are interactive are tabbed onto, hovered, clicked or are in focus.
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    Keyboard-only users will find it difficult to understand how to use a service, if a component doesn’t signal it can be interacted with.
  

Tools you can use


Acessibility Insights

19.title: Form elements include clearly associated labels
19.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Form elements include clearly associated labels
Form inputs such as textboxes, select lists, radio buttons and checkboxes must be labelled so that users can understand what is expected to be entered.
This helps users with cognitive, language or learning disabilities to input or select the necessary information in your service and reduce errors from being made.
This is a requirement of:





WCAG 1.3.1 - Information and relationships (Level A)







WCAG 3.3.2 - Labels or Instructions (Level A)


You should ensure that form inputs are correctly associated with a corresponding label by using the “for” attribute which matches the id of the input.
<label for="first-name">First name</label>
<input id="first-name" name="first-name" type="text">
In some instances a label can be visually hidden, these are still available to screen readers but hidden from sighted users.
This may be appropriate for search fields where other indicators indicate to the user what the field is, for example placeholder text and appropriate button icons or text.
If using GOV.UK Frontend you can use the following css class to achieve this:
<label class="govuk-visually-hidden" for="search-input">Search the website</label>


  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    All form inputs must have a corresponding label element. Use labels above inputs to help users remember what they are filling in.
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    Don’t use placeholders on their own. Placeholder text will dissapear when typing starts and users might forget what the field is for.
  

Tools you can use

20.title: Images and media contain alternative descriptions
20.content: window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || []; function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);} gtag('js', new Date()); gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ'); Back to standards Images and media contain alternative descriptions Media such as images, video and charts should contain a text alternative describing the media. This is a requirement of: WCAG 1.1.1 - Non-text content (Level A) For images, this is achieved by adding a description using the alt attribute, for example: For other media like video, this should be done using other means for example: closed captions (subtitles) sign language transcript audio description When you don’t need to use alternative text The image is purely decorative, like a background pattern The image content is represented by adjacent real text like a product description You should add ant alt attribute but leave it empty. Do Add alt text to images to describe them, this helps screen reader users understand images and describes the image if it fails to load. Don’t Missing alt text might make it more difficult for users to understand what is being presented to them. Tools you can use WCAG alt text decision tree (opens in new tab)

21.title: Standards
21.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');



Standards


  
    
      Important: 
      You’ll be assessed on these
    
  
   This page gives you guidance on the design standards you’ll be assessed on in DfE or CDDO service assessments

Working to defined standards ensure services the Department for Education (DfE) create are inclusive and accessible and can be used by all people.
This includes removing risk by designing how things should work, this can be achieved by:


working with other designers, researchers and developers to build and test prototypes
following inclusive design principles
ensuring you meet component design criteria
contributing to the GOV.UK Design System backlog (opens in new tab)
sharing your work with other designers across DfE
taking part in design crits, reviews and assessments to assure your designs are meeting these standards

Minimum design standards
The following standards are the minimum required for designers to meet.




    Branding the service
 How to ensure the service is using the correct header, logos and typeface for where it’s being provided.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard to ensure the service is branded correctly
  
   

            
            
          
  






    Ensure sufficient colour contrast between foreground and background
 Text and components must show up clearly against the background.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard to ensure sufficient colour contrast between foreground and background
  
   

  






    Do not use colour alone to convey information
 Do not use colour as the only way to explain or signal something.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    Make it easy for people to identify interactive elements
 Style components such as links and buttons to make them easy to identify in different states.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    Design interactions in a logical order
 Good tab stop design allows keyboard users to access a services interactive elements in a predictable order.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    Make navigation options clear and consistent across the service
 It should be easy to get around the service in a consistent way and for users to know where they are in a service.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    Include clearly associated labels on form elements
 Ensure that all forms have an identifiable label next to, or above the field.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    Make sure feedback to the user is clear and identifiable
 Tell users clearly if something is happening or they need to take action.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    Design for different viewports, ideally mobile-first
 Think about how users will interact with the service on different devices and how the design will change as a result.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    If you use images and media, make sure they have alternative descriptions
 Think about how to describe images, audio descriptions of video or transcripts.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard
  
   

  






    If you use content which starts automatically, make sure you include controls
 Allow the user to control or stop any animations or audio.
 Further guidance and how to meet this standard

22.title: Feedback to the user is clear and identifiable

23.title: Ensure sufficient contrast between foreground and background
23.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Back to standards
Ensure sufficient contrast between foreground and background
Text and components, like buttons, must be clearly perceivable from their background. This helps people who may not be able to distinguish colour (colour blindness) or have poor or low vision.
This is a requirement of:





WCAG 1.4.3 - Contrast (Minimum) (Level AA)


This does not apply for logos or text that is in a photograph.
The contrast ratio should be at least:


4.5:1 for text smaller than 24px, or 19px if bold
3:1 for text larger than 24px, or 19px if bold and components (like a text input field or button) and graphic elements (like an icon)

You should also check the colors you use work for people with colorblindness, and that color alone is not being used to convey meaning.


  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Do 
    
    Ensure text and components can be perceived from the background easily.
  
  
    
      
    
    
      
        
          
         Don’t 
    
    Users with vision problems, poor eyesight or color blindness will struggle to identify text and components with low contrast.
  

Tools you can use


WebAIM Contrast Checker
Contrast Grid - tool for checking a wide range of colour combinations against Levels AA and AAA
Contrast checker - Built by designers from within Government.
Colour contrast checker - Edge plugin to check web pages from within the browser.

24.title: Designs for different viewports are considered

25.title: Headings are used and related content is grouped together

26.title: Design community

27.title: Design assurance
27.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');



Design assurance
In addition to service assessments
 designers are expected to carry out activities which support in-line or team assurance of design activity.
This helps to reduce the risk of mistakes being made which may be costly to fix later on, getting feedback earlier in the design process and involving people who may not be designers to contribute feedback and a different point of view to yours.
This helps ensure your designs are inclusive, understandable and meet the standards outlined in this guidance.
Methods to assure design




    Design critiques (crits) and reviews
 Giving and receiveing feedback on design work as part of a team.
 How we do design crits in DfE
  
   

  






    Peer reviews / 2i
 2i, “proounced 2 eye” involves a peer in your profession reviewing or double-checking your work.
 How to get peer review feedback.
  
   

  






    Show and tells and show the thing
 How to run a succesful show and tell and engage people in your work.
 Find out more about running show and tells.
  
   

  






    Accessibility audits and testing
 Assurances that your service is meeting standards through testing, internal and external audits.
 Guidance on testing and requesting an audit.
  
   

  






    Service assessments
 These should not be seen as a tick box exercise but a conversation about how you have worked to meet user needs and the Service Standard.
 How service assessments are run in DfE.

28.title: Design critiques
28.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Design critiques
Giving and receiving feedback on work is an important part of the design process. In DfE, these are often called design crits, some teams in DfE refer to these as collaborative design reviews.
By running or taking part in a crit or review, you are contributing to the design process by:


increasing the awareness and visibility of design in DfE
getting a different perspective on yours or others work
contributing to improving the design process
help make decisions, give advice or guidance
giving people a voice where they may otherwise be excluded



Another benefit of running a design crit or review is that accessibility issues can be identified early.

Running a crit or design review in DfE
The design profession has created a lightweight framework for running a review session.
Giving and receiving feedback on work is an important part of the design process. By doing design critiques or “crits” you are getting feedback from different people, identifying any problems early on and getting a different perspective on your work.
Similar to the rules of the retrospective, design crits should understand that “everyone did the best job they could with the information they had at the time.”
There are 3 primary rules of a design crit:


Talk about the product or service, not the person
Be honest but kind and use constructive criticism only
No-one should need to defend a position

1. Talk about the product or service, not the person
In a crit, never talk about the person who has done the work, talk about the product or service. You are there to improve the product.
When giving feedback, instead of: “This doesn’t work as an accordion as it’s not showing me everything I need to know” you could say “Have you considered using just headers and paragraphs to display the content?”
This helps a discussion as the designer may have considered it and has a valid reason that they have not used the suggestion. This can help help a discussion about the decisions that have been made and build understanding.
When asking for feedback it’s also important that you give some background on what you want to get feedback on and what you want to find out.
2. Be honest but kind and use constructive criticism only
A crit is a safe place to talk, share feedback and also listen. Being rude, dismissive or obnoxious isn’t going to help the design, the product or team relationships.
Thinking about how you give feedback is important, for example: instead of “you never use the display component properly” to “check the usage examples for the display component in the Design System.”
Questions rather than statements can lead to better discussions in a design crit.
It’s also important as the person requesting feedback, to listen, let people take in the work and get notes of what people say and why.
3. No-one should need to defend a position
If you are designing as a team, no one person on the team should feel like they need to defend anything. Everyone is working on the thing - as a team - learning together.
Read the GOV.UK Blog on using design crits to improve collaboration (opens in new tab)

29.title: Component design
29.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Component design
When designing a new service, always start with what is available already. Check the GOV.UK Design System  before designing anything new because those patterns and components have already been researched and tested to make sure they’re accessible.
If you design anything new, your team will have to do all of the user research and accessibility testing and audit work to make sure that it is meeting the needs of your users and the accessibility standards.
If your service is only for staff or if won’t be GOV.UK branded, it is still recommended to use the GOV.UK Design System and its unbranded layout. You will still get the benefits of the accessibility work that has gone into it. For example resizing the screen, the line spacing and the components.
Four stage acceptance criteria
If the GOV.UK Design System doesn’t feature a component which you can use to meet a user need, you can use the 4 stage acceptance criteria to validate if building a new component is the right thing to do.
This does not stop new components from being created, but instead puts some checks in place to prevent over-engineering of service frontends.


Can the problem be solved with existing components or patterns?
Does it meet user needs across multiple services?
Does it add value to the user experience?
Is it accessible?

1. Can the problem be solved with existing components or patterns?
The primary look and feel for digital services is the GOV.UK Frontend with available components, patterns and styles detailed in the GOV.UK Design System.
Where appropriate, contributions should be made back to the design system to support the development of components for other users.
The GOV.UK Design System backlog also contains components which are being considered or in development or have been built by other designers.
If you decide the problem cannot be designed around by anything that exists in the design system, and it is a common problem, ask within DfE or Gov Digital slack channels to see if anyone else has designed for the same problem.


interaction-design (DfE Slack)
developers (DfE Slack)
design (GOV Digital Slack) 
govuk-design-system (GOV Digital Slack)

2. Does it meet user needs across multiple services?
Designers can often work in silos and as a result aren’t aware of what other designers across DfE are working on and designing. This becomes obvious, and a pain point, for users of multiple DfE services which have been designed and built by different teams.
Using components consistently, sharing with other designers and understanding who the users are and which services they use, helps to provide a consistent experience of DfE services and will help you to meet the following standards:


 Service Standard point 3 - provide a joined up experience across all channels
 WCAG 3.2.4 (AA) - Consistent identification

3. Does it add value to the user experience?
When designing a new component, you should be ensuring it is meeting a validated user need through user research activity. Designing components and features which meet user’s needs, should be shared so that other designers can use them in their services.
Components and features shouldn’t be built or designed just to make something look aesthetically pleasing, but instead add value, solve a problem or make something complex, understandable.
4. Is it accessible?
Accessibility is non-negotiable. Any new components or features must meet the component design guidelines and be usable by people of all abilities.
When considering a new component, it will often go through several iterations and design decisions will be made on what to take forward and what to discard, often through design crits, show and tells and user research.
Involving a wide range of people in these decisions will ensure you are being inclusive in your design approach.
You can read the full guidance for accessibility acceptance criteria for components on GOV.UK
Find out more
The following links open in a new tab


Designing for different browsers and devices
GOV.UK Frontend coding standards

30.title: Principles

31.title: Ways of working

32.title: Interaction design
32.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Interaction design
The purpose of interaction design is to design user interfaces and the interactions between the user and a service. Interaction design is applicable throughout the agile delivery phases: Discovery, Alpha, Beta and Live.
Additionally, interaction designers work on legacy services and rolling out changes to ensure DfE’s services are consistent and meet current standards and regulations.
Standards and guidelines
By using these standards and guidelines we ensure design services that:


meet the Service Standard in DfE
meet current web guidelines outlined in WCAG 2.1 as applied through the public sector accessibility regulations.
meet user and organisational needs
are simple and intuitive to use
work in a way that is familiar
require the minimum possible steps to complete
are consistent throughout
are usable by everyone, equally

Find out more about the standards designers are required to meet in DfE.

33.title: Inclusive design standards in interaction design
33.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Inclusive design
Inclusive design aims to remove barriers that create extra effort for some groups of users. It is a design methodology that enables and draws on the full range of human diversity
If we use our own abilities and biases as a starting point, we end up with services designed for people of a specific gender, age, language ability, tech literacy, and physical ability.
Like accessibility, this includes individuals with physical or mental impairments, but it also goes much further than this. Inclusivity includes users of all ethnicities, backgrounds, gender, sexual orientation, and more into the user experience.
In short, inclusivity means design that is both representative and accessible.
Writing inclusivley
When we write, we may be introducing bias without realising it. We may also be using language that is gender specific when it shouldn’t be.
You can use the inclusivity settings in Office 365 to check the language of content in documents.


        
        
       Important: Enabling inclusivity checker in Office 365
        Go to: Editor > Settings > Inclusivity and tick the boxesThe spellchecker will now help you to start writing inclusive language and avoid any subconscious bias.
        
There’s no such thing as a “normal user”
The interactions we design with technology depend heavily on what we can see, hear, say, and touch.
Assuming all those senses and abilities are fully enabled all the time creates the potential to ignore many people who may have impairments with one or more of their senses.
Designing for inclusivity not only opens up Department for Education (DfE) services to more people with a wider range of abilities. It also reflects how people really are.
Recognise exclusion in design
Exclusion happens when we solve problems or design solutions using our own biases.
There are different ways someone can be excluded from using a service through disability and is dependent on the context of how people are using the service.
There are three types of exclusion designers must consider when designing services, components and features.
Temporary
Short term injury or context affects how users interact with the service. For example, having a broken arm may make it more difficult to use a phone, computer or mouse and keyboard.
[ Example: How you can do this
]
Situational
The situation a user finds themself in might mean they cannot use the service at that moment in time. For example, being in a loud environment might make it difficult to hear or speak to someone on the phone if they need help using a service.
[ Example: How you can do this
]
Permanent
Many people have a permanent disability and so designing for these users by default means the service will work for more people. For example, ensuring a service works with screen readers will work for a wide range of people.
[ Example: How you can do this
]
Build knowledge in diversity
Inclusive design helps you to ensure you meet Service Standard points 1. understand users and their needs and 5. everyone can use the service.
Do not rely solely on simulating different abilities. For example, using blindfolds, earplugs or putting one hand behind your back, test the service with a wide range of users.
Having empathy for your users and learning how people adapt in different ways to using the service, you can better understand how to design for a wide range of abilities.
Solve for one, works for all
Inclusive design means designing with consideration for many different circumstances.
However, ensuring the service works for blind users has the added benefit that it’ll work for users with temporary vision issues using voice over or a screen reader.
Additionally, someone who might find it easier to listen to guidance or content rather than read it if they are cooking dinner or out for a walk.
Find out more
The following links all open in a new tab.


Making your service more inclusive on GOV.UK
Inclusive Design Nielsen Norman Group
Inclusive Design Toolkit Microsoft

34.title: Accessibility
34.content:
window.dataLayer = window.dataLayer || [];
  function gtag(){dataLayer.push(arguments);}
  gtag('js', new Date());

  gtag('config', 'G-D2V3LRNYBJ');

Accessibility
For designers, there are specific WCAG guidelines which should be followed when designing components.


  
    
      Principle
      Guideline criteria
      Level
    
  
     
      
      Perceivable
      1.3.1 - Info and Relationships 
      A 
    
         
      Perceivable
      1.3.3 - Sensory Characteristics 
      A 
    
             
      Perceivable
      1.4.1 - Use of Color 
      A 
    
    
      Perceivable
      1.4.1 - Audio Control 
      A 
    
      
      Perceivable
      1.4.4 - Resize text 
      AA 
    
          
      Operable
      2.1.1 - Keyboard 
      A 
    
     
      Operable
      2.1.2 - No Keyboard Trap 
      A 
    
     
      Operable
      2.2.1 - Timing Adjustable 
      A 
    
     
      Operable
      2.2.2 - Pause, Stop, Hide 
      A 
    
     
      Operable
      2.3.1 - Three Flashes or Below Threshold 
      A 
    
     
      Operable
      2.4.4 - Link Purpose (In Context) 
      A 
    
     
      Operable
      2.4.4 - Multiple Ways 
      AA 
    
     
      Operable
      2.4.6 - Headings and Labels 
      AA 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.2.1 - On Focus 
      A 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.2.2 - On Input 
      A 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.3.1 - Error Identification 
      A 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.3.2 - Labels or Instructions 
      A 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.2.3 - Consistent Navigation 
      AA 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.2.4 - Consistent Identification 
      AA 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.3.3 - Error Suggestion 
      AA 
    
     
      Understandable
      3.3.4 -  Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data) 
      AA 
    
     
      Robust
      4.1.2 - Name, Role, Value 
      A 
    
  



const cards = document.querySelectorAll('.card');
Array.prototype.forEach.call(cards, card => {
    let down, up, link = card.querySelector('h2 a');
    card.style.cursor = 'pointer';
    card.onmousedown = () => down = +new Date();
    card.onmouseup = () => {
        up = +new Date();
        if ((up - down) < 200) {
            link.click();
        }
    }
});

Design in DfE
This guidance helps teams understand how to design services in DfE.




    Content design
 Content standards for how we write for DfE services.
 More about content design in DfE
  
   

  






    Interaction design
 Standards, guidelines and good practice for designing accessible, useable and consistent DfE services.
 More about interaction design in DfE
  
   

  






    Service design
 How to ensure the service is using the correct header, logos and typeface for where it’s being provided.
